en: Interview with Paige Braddock, Chief Creative Officer for Charles Shulz's studio and former East Tennessee resident, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Braddock discusses her time in East Tennessee and relates her California wildfire experiences to the wildfire in Gatlinburg. She explains how her experiences have helped her create artwork for the Gatlinburg wildfire. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "If there is a story or an event or something that is almost impossible to illustrate with a photograph, sometimes a drawing or illustration can get to the heart of that so that you're not so much showing a representation of something that happened, but you're getting at the emotion behind what happened."

Interview with Paige Braddock, Chief Creative Officer for Charles Shulz's studio and former East Tennessee resident, conducted by Casey Kaufman. Braddock discusses her time in East Tennessee and relates her California wildfire experiences to the wildfire in Gatlinburg. She explains how her experiences have helped her create artwork for the Gatlinburg wildfire. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: "If there is a story or an event or something that is almost impossible to illustrate with a photograph, sometimes a drawing or illustration can get to the heart of that so that you're not so much showing a representation of something that happened, but you're getting at the emotion behind what happened."

Can you state your name and tell us about yourself?
I know you're also the author of Jane's World. Can you talk about that?
How did you find your career in illustration?
Would you share your perspective on how visual storytelling helps shape public understanding of events like the wildfire of 2016?
Can you talk about your time spent in the East Tennessee region?
Can you talk about when you first became aware of the wildfire?
Is there anything you want to share about the comparisons or contrasts of disasters with fire out west versus in the east?
Can you describe what it was like listening to people tell their experiences of this event?
Can you walk us through your artistic process of producing art out of these stories?
Was the process of creating art out of moving images something new for you?
Did any thoughts come to mind as you were telling the story of this wildfire disaster during the midst of the ongoing COVID-19 disaster?
Is there anything we haven't talked about that you would like to share?

seo.title: Interview with Paige Braddock, 2022-01-14 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories

She explains how her experiences have helped her create artwork for the Gatlinburg wildfire. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
